title: AB 1685
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. A person violating provisions of Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code may be subject to a civil penalty of up to $37,500 per action. Violations related to portable fuel containers or small off-road engines may incur a penalty of up to $500 per unit. Manufacturers or distributors who violate these provisions may also face penalties. For violations of emission control laws, manufacturers or distributors may face penalties and be required to make their products compliant as a condition for continued sale in the state. The state board adjusts maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties collected are deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43151 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Section 43151 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require certification for new motor vehicles or engines in California. Penalties collected will go to the Air Pollution Control Fund. This article exempts certain vehicles from regulations if acquired to replace a damaged or stolen vehicle, transferred by inheritance or court decree, or sold after a specific legislative session. The article exempts certain vehicles from regulations if acquired to replace a damaged or stolen vehicle, transferred by inheritance or court decree, or sold after a specific legislative session. Vehicles sold after the effective date of amendments at the 1979-80 Regular Session of the Legislature are also exempt. This chapter does not apply to motor vehicles with a certificate of conformity under the federal Clean Air Act, originally registered in another state by a resident who moves to this state and provides evidence of previous registration. This exemption becomes effective 180 days after regulations are adopted for certifying new direct import vehicles. Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for violations of emission control laws. Manufacturers or distributors may also be required to pay the penalty and ensure compliance with laws to continue selling vehicles in the state. The state board may impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 on dealers who violate emission control laws, with adjustments for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. Any action to recover a penalty under this section shall be brought in the name of the people of the State of California in the superior court of the county where the violation occurred, by the Attorney General on behalf of the state board, or by the district attorney, county attorney, or city attorney. Penalties adjudged by the court shall be deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code states that a new motor vehicle sold in California must meet emission standards set by the state board. Manufacturers selling vehicles that do not meet these standards may face a civil penalty of up to $37,500 per violation. The civil penalty for failure to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements in California is capped at $5,000 per credit. The state board will adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. Any penalty recovered under this section will go into the General Fund. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for each vehicle that does not comply with emission standards or test procedures. Non-compliant manufacturers or distributors may also be required to pay penalties to the state board and ensure vehicles meet emission control laws before further sale in the state. The state board will adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Any penalty recovered will be deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43214 is added to the Health and Safety Code. The state board may order a manufacturer to bring its vehicles into compliance with certified emissions configuration, with compliance required for continued sale in the state. Any penalty recovered will go to the Air Pollution Control Fund.
